name: Cogmaster-stats
tagline: Companion website for the cogmaster-stats workshop
body: ## Welcome to the cogmaster-stats class General annoucements about this class will be made on Twitter. Follow [@cogmasterstats](https://twitter.com/cogmasterstats) to stay current with the latest news. **Time and place:** ENS 45, rue d'Ulm, Salle Beckett; 9:00–11:30, every Tuesday (starting October 8th.) You should bring your personal laptop for all sessions. Internet is available on demand, but you won't need it to follow the course. It is recommended to check-out the [project page](https://github.com/cogmaster-stats/), or update your own Git repository, each week. If you want to check R data files individually, please visit the [slides](https://github.com/cogmaster-stats/r-cogstats/tree/master/slides) or [labs](https://github.com/cogmaster-stats/r-cogstats/tree/master/labs) directories. ## Lectures The R statistical software will be used during the first six courses. The [Setup](#setup) section contains additional information to install R and RStudio. The following open-access textbook will be used along the course. > Diez, DM, Barr, CD, and Çetinkaya-Rundel, M (2012). [OpenIntro Statistics](http://www.openintro.org/stat/) (2nd edition). For a general description of this workshop, see this [Overview](http://rpubs.com/chl/cogmaster-stats-00-overview). Here is a temptative timetable for the R part (15 hours in total, it might be subjected to changes), with slides and practicals (R code available on the main Github repository): ### 1. Introduction to R 1. [Working with data](http://rpubs.com/chl/cogmaster-stats-01-intro) (slides) 2. [Getting started with R](http://rpubs.com/chl/cogmaster-stats-01-lab) (lab notes), with [selected answers](http://rpubs.com/chl/cogmaster-stats-01-ans) **Readings:** OpenIntro Statistics 1.3-1.7, 4.1, 4.3, 4.6, 5.4 **Homeworks:** None ### 2. Descriptive statistics and two-group comparisons 1. [Exploratory Data Analysis and Statistical Inference](http://rpubs.com/chl/cogmaster-stats-02-infer) (slides) 2. [Data munging and basic statistical tests with R](http://rpubs.com/chl/cogmaster-stats-02-lab) (lab notes) **Readings:** OpenIntro Statistics 4.2, 5.2, 5.5 **Extra readings:** Tukey, J.W. [We Need Both Exploratory and Confirmatory](http://www.aliquote.org/cours/2013_AS/docs/Tukey1980.pdf), The American Statistician (1980) 34(1):23-25; Wickham, H. [The Split-Apply-Combine Strategy for Data Analysis](http://www.jstatsoft.org/v40/i01/), Journal of Statistical Software (2011) 40(1). **Homeworks:** [1-5](http://rpubs.com/chl/cogmaster-stats-exercises) **Note:** If after this session you are still unsure about what you have learned regarding basic data manipulation in R, you are encouraged to complete the first 5 chapters on at home. ### 3. ANOVA and design of experiments (Oct. 22) 1. [Statistical Models in R](http://rpubs.com/chl/cogmaster-stats-03-anova) (slides) 2. [Analysis of variance with R](http://rpubs.com/chl/cogmaster-stats-03-lab) (lab notes) **Readings:** OpenIntro Statistics 7.1-7.4 **Extra readings:** Lang, T. [Common statistical errors even you can find - Part 1: Errors in descriptive statistics and in interpreting probability values](http://www.aliquote.org/cours/2013_AS/docs/Statistical_Errors_Part1.pdf), AMWA Journal (2003) 18(2):67-71. Lang, T. [Common statistical errors even you can find - Part 2: Errors in multivariate analyses and in interpreting differences between groups](http://www.aliquote.org/cours/2013_AS/docs/Statistical_Errors_Part2.pdf), AMWA Journal (2003) 18(3):103-107. **Homeworks:** [6-10](http://rpubs.com/chl/cogmaster-stats-exercises) **Solutions:** [1-5](http://rpubs.com/chl/cogmaster-stats-solutions) ### 4. Linear regression (Nov. 5) ### 5. More advanced ANOVA settings (Nov. 12) ### 6. Other regression models (Nov. 19) ## Setup ### R setup You should already have R and RStudio. If they are not installed on your system, please follow these instructions: 1. Go to and select a binary package for your system. 2. Go to and download RStudio Desktop. There is often a [Preview Release](http://www.rstudio.com/ide/download/preview) that include additional functionalities but is still considered in beta stage. Install both software as is usually done on your system. At this point, you may want to test that everything is ok: Launch RStudio and check that the R prompt is available in the *Console* panel (it is usually sitting on the right). You can further check that R is working as expected by typing (without the prompt sign, `>`) > 1/3 == 0.3 at the R prompt. Don't worry if the result (`FALSE`) doesn't match your expectation, we will learn why later. You can customize RStudio layout under File ▹ Preferences. At some point, we will make use of the [R Markdown](http://www.rstudio.com/ide/docs/authoring/using_markdown) language to document our working sessions. You don't need to install anything other than RStudio, but you may want to install [Pandoc](http://johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc/), which is a tool for converting among markup formats and generate HTML or PDF documents based on a Markdown file. As an alternative to RStudio built-in facilities, you can install an enhanced Markdwon processor: [MultiMarkdown](http://fletcherpenney.net/multimarkdown/). ### Pick up a good editor Sometimes, it is easier to work directly from a text editor. There are several good editors available for free and working on all platforms (Windows, Un*x, and OS X), including these ones: * [Emacs](http://www.gnu.org/s/emacs/); the [ESS mode](http://ess.r-project.org/) provides everything you need to interact with R. * [Vim](http://vim.org/); the [Vim-R-plugin](http://www.vim.org/scripts/script.php?script_id=2628) offers allows communicating with an R process directly. * [Sublime Text](http://www.sublimetext.com/2) 2 or 3 (free for evaluation purpose, $70 for continued use); syntax highlighting for R is already available, and the [SublimeREPL](http://sublimerepl.readthedocs.org/en/latest/) package also allows communicating with an R process. ### Git If you want to experiment with [Git](http://git-scm.com/) and if it is not already installed on your system, go download the latest version of Git. When installation is completed, check that it is available on your system by typing (again, without the prompt sign, `$`) $ git --version in a Terminal. Windows users may have to use a specific GUI. You can request an [educational account](https://github.com/edu) on Github. This will allow you to create private repositories that you can use for your course work. Or you can create an account on [BitBucket](https://bitbucket.org/), which offers unlimited private repositories for personal use. In any case, you can follow the course and download the latest archive of the course on [Github](https://github.com/cogmaster-stats). ### Useful readings * Kieran Healy (2010). [Choosing Your Workflow Applications](http://kieranhealy.org/files/misc/workflow-apps.pdf) (PDF) * Oliver Kirchkamp (2011). [Workﬂow of statistical data analysis](http://www.kirchkamp.de/oekonometrie/pdf/wf-screen2.pdf) (PDF) * Aedin Culhane (2012). [Sweave and Reproducible Research](http://bcb.dfci.harvard.edu/~aedin/courses/ReproducibleResearch/) (WWW) ------ **Note:** This site is in construction. More information will be added soon (Grading policy, Homeworks, etc.).
